text: The ground suddenly quaked. A beast covered in rocky armor burst out from the soil, its eyes glowing green as its roar echoed through the forest.
Instinctively, I stepped back—but my foot slipped on a patch of moss. Before I could react, the beast lunged, its claws tearing through the air.
Pain shot up my arm. I grunted, feeling warm blood trickle down my sleeve. The creature’s breath was hot, pressing down on me like a storm.
A sudden gust cut through the air—Alicia leapt from the right, cloak swirling. Her boot struck the beast’s jaw before she drew her sword in one smooth motion.
A flash of silver—her blade sliced cleanly across the monster’s neck.
The creature let out a final roar before collapsing with a heavy thud. Dust rose; sparks danced along the edge of her sword.
The air smelled of iron and ash. Alicia sheathed her sword and knelt before me, checking the wound.
She tore a strip from her cloak and wrapped my arm swiftly. The firelight caught her face, and for the first time, her cold expression seemed soft.
“This kind of beast isn’t born naturally... it’s a ‘Residual Dream.’”
“Residual Dream?” I echoed, my voice still trembling.
“Mm. In places where wars were fought or people died, the ground keeps their last emotions. Over time, those emotions take shape.”
Her tone was calm, yet carried a faint chill.
“Don’t worry. This forest’s still far from the town.”
I nodded. She helped me to my feet, steadying me. Once she saw I could stand, her voice grew lighter again.
“Good.” She looked toward the sunlight filtering through the trees, a faint smile on her lips. “The market’s just ahead. The weather’s quite nice today.”
